item.title: At Least 55 Dead in Hong Kong Apartment Fire
item.description: Firefighters were still trying to fully extinguish the blaze more than 24 hours after it engulfed several towers in the complex. Dozens of people were still missing.

item.title: Hong Kongers Volunteer to Help Fire Victims
item.description: Residents from across the city have quickly organized to donate food, water, clothing and other supplies in Tai Po for the many displaced people.

item.title: What to Know About the Deadly Fire at a Hong Kong Apartment Complex
item.description: At least 75 people were killed in the most lethal fire in Hong Kong in nearly 70 years. Firefighters have extinguished the blaze in half of the buildings.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Worst Fire in Decades Fuels Scrutiny of Safety Lapses
item.description: The authorities said flammable netting and foam boards may have fueled the city’s deadliest blaze in nearly 70 years, killing at least 75 and prompting arrests.

item.title: Heading to the Mideast, Pope Leo May Show ‘Who He Really Is’
item.description: The pontiff begins a trip to Turkey and Lebanon on Thursday — the first foreign voyage of his papacy, and his biggest test yet.

item.title: Pope Leo Lands in Turkey, Planning to Meet Erdogan With a Message of Outreach
item.description: In the capital, Ankara, Leo XIV was received by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on the opening leg of a trip that will also include Lebanon.

item.title: Pope Leo Visits Turkey on His First Trip as Pontiff
item.description: The pope started his six-day trip, which will also include a visit to Lebanon.

item.title: Images From the Deadly High-Rise Fire in Hong Kong
item.description: The blaze tore through an apartment complex, killing at least 55 people. Dozens more are believed to be missing in what remains of the buildings.

item.title: The British Public Thinks Immigration Is Up. It’s Actually Down, Sharply.
item.description: Net migration to Britain has fallen by almost 80 percent from its 2023 peak, according to data released on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Cut Europe Out of Ukraine Talks. Here’s How Europe Pushed Back.
item.description: European leaders were blindsided by President Trump’s 28-point-plan to end the Ukraine war, setting off a dash for influence.

item.title: France Creates Voluntary Military Service as Europe Faces Russian Threat
item.description: The effort is aimed at young people and came after an army chief angered many by saying the country must accept the possible loss of children in a future war.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
‘No Alarm Went Off’: Hong Kong Fire Survivor Recounts Harrowing Escape
item.description: Many windows were covered, preventing residents from seeing the fire and smoke, one survivor said.

item.title: Trump shuts the door to Afghans who face crises at home.
Hong Kong Arrests 3 Tied to Construction Company After Deadly Apartment Fire
item.description: The police said that building materials used by the company for the work at Wang Fuk Court may not have been up to fire safety standards. The police did not identify the company or who was arrested.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: Firefighters tried to douse the blaze at an apartment complex in the city’s northern Tai Po district, which killed at least four people.

item.title: An Asia-Pacific Showdown
item.description: China and Japan are in a diplomatic feud over Taiwan, with President Trump in the middle.

item.title: Miroslaw Chojecki, Solidarity’s ‘Minister of Smuggling,’ Dies at 76
item.description: First in Warsaw and later from Paris, he supplied anti-Communist activists in Poland with steady stream of leaflets, newsletters and banned books.

item.title: U.K. Budget Plan Calms Markets and Labour Faithful. Will It Appeal to Voters?
item.description: The plan presented by the chancellor of the Exchequer, Rachel Reeves, called for spending increases and higher taxes on the wealthy and the middle class.

item.title: U.S. to Press Europe and Other Allies on Immigration, Document Says
item.description: American diplomats were told to raise U.S. concerns about “violent crimes associated with people of a migration background.”

item.title: Guinea-Bissau’s President Says He Has Been Deposed. The Opposition Says It’s a Trick.
item.description: The military announced on Wednesday it had taken over the West African nation. Later, the opposition leader accused the incumbent president of staging the coup d’état to try to retain power.

item.title: Trump Says South Africa Is Not Invited to G20 Summit in U.S. in 2026
item.description: The president did not attend this year’s annual gathering in South Africa, which has been a frequent target of his attacks.

item.title: Deadly, fast-moving fire is less likely in Midtown Manhattan, experts say.
item.description: The area’s high-rises have robust safety features and are not as densely packed as those in Hong Kong, making them less susceptible to blazes.

item.title: E.P.A. Delays Requirements to Cut Methane, a Potent Greenhouse Gas
item.description: Oil and gas firms were supposed to start reducing methane, a powerful driver of climate change. The agency is giving them more time and may cancel the requirement.

item.title: As Trade Talks Stall, Carney Moves to Shield Canada from Trump Tariffs
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced curbs on steel imports, a new tariff and help with steel and lumber freight costs in a bid to aid Canadian industries.

item.title: Dubrovnik, Known for Its Beauty, Faces a Mound of New Trash
item.description: Officials in Dubrovnik, Croatia, say the strong currents of the Adriatic Sea washed ashore a vast amount of garbage, mostly from Albania, during a recent storm.

item.title: Top U.S. Negotiator Warned Europeans That Russia Is Stockpiling Missiles
item.description: Daniel P. Driscoll, the U.S. Army secretary, used the growing threat from Moscow as a way to sell a quick peace deal unfavorable to Ukraine.

item.title: Hong Kong Fire Shared Similarities With Grenfell Tower Fire in London
item.description: In the Grenfell Tower blaze, a combustible element called cladding that ran up the outside of the 24-story building allowed the fire to jump from floor to floor.

item.title: Hong Kong Residents Describe How Apartment Fire Quickly Spread
item.description: Residents describe how a blaze in a high-rise building in Hong Kong quickly spread, taking many by surprise and trapping an unknown number of people in the burning buildings.

item.title: The Question Hanging Over Peace Talks: What Will Putin Accept?
item.description: A U.S. proposal may cross a number of red lines for the Russian leader, who sees little to lose and much potentially to gain from continuing to fight.

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy, Former French President, Loses Corruption Appeal
item.description: France’s highest court has upheld a conviction against Nicolas Sarkozy, who led France until 2012. It comes weeks after he was jailed in a different fraud trial.

item.title: Italy Passes a Femicide Law, Seeking to Prevent Violence Against Women
item.description: Murders of women killed for misogynistic reasons will now be classified as femicide. Campaigners say a broader cultural shift is still needed.

item.title: ‘Imperial Israel’ in the New Middle East
item.description: Despite a cease-fire with Hezbollah, almost daily strikes demonstrate an emboldened Israel’s strategy to eliminate its enemies any time, anywhere.

item.title: Joan Branson, Richard Branson’s Wife of 35 Years, Dies at 80
item.description: Mr. Branson, the Virgin Group founder and one of Britain’s best known business figures, announced her death in an Instagram post.

item.title: Amid Strobes and a Beat Drop, Pope Blesses Rave-Goers
item.description: A papal video message appeared before a crowd of hundreds in Slovakia, as Guilherme Peixoto, a priest who doubles as an electronic D.J., put on a show.

item.title: Eli Zeira, 97, Dies; Israeli Official Dismissed Warnings of Yom Kippur War
item.description: As Israel’s head of military intelligence, he disregarded signs Egypt and Syria were about to attack in 1973. A commission blamed him for the lack of preparation.

item.title: Tai Po is a crucial link between Hong Kong and mainland China.
item.description: The city

item.title: At Miss Universe, Miss Norway’s Salmon Costume Steals the Show
item.description: The designer behind Miss Norway’s wild outfit wasn’t surprised by the attention. “The original plan was to make noise.”

item.title: The last time Hong Kong had a major fire was 2008.
item.description: The last five-alarm fire in Hong Kong engulfed a 15-story building in the Mong Kong district, killing four people.

item.title: Deadly Flooding in Thailand Prompts Rescues and Evacuations
item.description: The military sent troops, helicopters and boats to rescue stranded people. At least 33 people have been killed and more than two million displaced over the past week.

item.title: Venezuela’s Nobel Peace Prize Winner Pushes False Claims About Maduro
item.description: Opposition leader Maria Corina Machado faces criticism that she is exaggerating threats posed by Venezuela’s leader to justify U.S. force to overthrow him.

item.title: Jakarta Overtakes Tokyo as World’s Largest City, UN Report Says
item.description: The capital of Indonesia surpassed Tokyo as the world’s most populous city after the United Nations overhauled how it measures urban populations.

item.title: Taiwan’s President to Seek an Extra $40 Billion for Military
item.description: President Lai Ching-te says the spending, which must be approved by the island’s legislature, would fund purchases of arms from the United States.

item.title: What’s Really Going On With Crime in South Africa
item.description: Police statistics in South Africa dispute President Trump’s claim that Afrikaners are being targeted in a genocide, but the high murder rate includes victims of all backgrounds. John Eligon, our Johannesburg bureau chief, traveled with several patrol groups in communities of South Africa to explore how the country is dealing with crime.

item.title: Trump Vowed Fewer Regulations and Lots More Oil. He’s Delivered on One.
item.description: The president’s energy strategy is projected to generate more pollution, but so far production has not risen significantly and price drops have been modest, analysts say.

item.title: Pope Leo to Visit Turkey and Lebanon
item.description: Leo XIV will meet political and religious leaders in Turkey and Lebanon, providing an early test of his geopolitical mettle. Here’s what to know.

item.title: Spat With China Becomes an Asset for Japan’s New Leader
item.description: Japan’s prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, is not backing off from comments about Taiwan that enraged China. Many of Japan’s voters like her stance.

item.title: Violence Is Driving Catastrophic Hunger in Nigeria, U.N. Report Says
item.description: Africa’s most populous nation was already facing one of the world’s biggest hunger crises. It’s getting much worse.

item.title: Hamas Says It Returned Body of Another Hostage From Gaza
item.description: Israel confirmed the remains belonged to Dror Or, 48, who was abducted during Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks. The bodies of two captives are believed to be still in Gaza.

item.title: Crunchtime for Europe on Ukraine
item.description: President Trump’s peace plan is forcing the continent to confront some hard choices about military power.

item.title: ‘You Start Getting Desperate’: How It Feels to Be Young and Jobless in Britain
item.description: Rising youth unemployment is one of the challenges that will affect the success of the British chancellor’s economic approach as she unveils a crucial budget on Wednesday.

item.title: Penny Oleksiak, Canadian Swimmer, Faces 2-Year Ban Over Antidoping Testing Rules
item.description: Penny Oleksiak, 25, who has won seven Olympic medals, was sanctioned under antidoping rules. Her suspension ends before the 2028 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles.

item.title: The 2026 Putin Calendar Is Here: ‘ A Man for Every Season’
item.description: January shows the Russian leader astride a snowmobile. For February, he flips a judo partner. In August, he offers advice: “My recipe for energy: Sleep little, work a lot and don’t whine.”

item.title: BBC Accused of Censoring Trump by Dutch Historian Rutger Bregman
item.description: Rutger Bregman said his comment that President Trump was the “most openly corrupt president in American history” was removed before his lecture was broadcast on Tuesday.

item.title: Bolsonaro To Start Serving 27-Year Prison Sentence Over Coup Plot
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court ordered former President Jair Bolsonaro to begin serving a prison term for conspiring to remain in power after losing the last election.

item.title: Minority Alawites Protest in Syria After Sectarian Attacks
item.description: The demonstrations followed unrest over the weekend in Homs, Syria’s third-largest city, which set off reprisal attacks on Alawites, a community once favored by the ousted Assad regime.
